What's the alternative? Exit bespoke CNNs, enter foundation brain models. Same recipe as NLP: pretrain on large (image | sound) datasets, adapt on brain data, fine-tune on specialty brain data. Trained by the community. Models shared through HuggingFace or other model zoos 11/11

So why haven't we abandoned CNNs wholesale as models of the visual cortex? A few reasons: 
- takes a lot of compute to fit a ViT
- not enough brain data to fit a ViT end-to-end
- benchmarks like @brain_score  not very sensitive to spatial non-stationarities 10/

Furthermore, ViTs seem to resolve one particular issue with CNNs as a model of the ventral stream, texture bias. Very large ViTs are currently the least texture-biased models of visual recognition we know of! 9/ https://t.co/KfpUYsokch https://t.co/QYnY7tnUjA
Some example includes CLIP  (https://t.co/QwqnXBV2wn), CrossViT (https://t.co/G12fPBUjNw), V1T in mice (https://t.co/5KJMxpH314). 8/

Furthermore, we're seeing that transformer architectures, which don't impose translation invariance as a structural prior, are SOTA or close to SOTA in explaining the ventral visual stream and beyond. 7/

CNN architectures like AlexNet and VGG break equivariance using fully connected layers. It turns out these are better matched to the brain than CNNs which use global pooling and maintain equivariance throughout, like ResNets, mobilenets, etc. 6/ https://t.co/MlFzxQmicI

Convolutions are the natural solution to creating equivariant representations of images under translation (https://t.co/z1XMLoNyfg). We know, however, that natural images statistics are not stationary, e.g. ground is different than sky 5/

I wrote about this 2 years ago on my blog: https://t.co/2yKaJZ5R6p. A lot of questions were still up in the air back then. I think we've seen pretty clear indications since then that there's a strong impedance mismatch between CNNs and the ventral visual stream 4/

In a reversal of the inspiration arrow, CNNs were later found to be best-in-class models of the ventral stream, from the likes of @dyamins and @KriegeskorteLab. But there's a problem: we don't know of a way that the brain can implement weight sharing. 3/

There's a long line history of visual processing inspiring convolutional neural nets, starting with the Nobel prize physiology work of Hubel & Wiesel inspiring Fukushima & @ylecun , which eventually lead to Alex Krizhevsky & the 2012 ImageNet moment 2/

The underlying issue is that the goal of AGI (to serve an existing agent, which is human) is different than the "goal" of evolution (to create agents which can survive). I don't see how recapitulating a process aligned with the wrong subgoals will lead us to our end goal 4/4

Insofar as the intelligence of a cat- or dog-level AI is mostly about soft-body motor planning, I fail to see how this intermediate-level AI would be useful. To put it bluntly, are we trying to build robot cats? Or are we trying to relieve the tedium of human existence? 3/

In order for these AIs to be useful, they don't need to be human-level across the board. Current generation AI is both super-human in some ways (e.g. capable of ingesting far more information than a human), and in other ways far worse (e.g. common sense). 2/

I have trouble engaging with this argument. Cats, dogs and humans are agents, with their own motivations. I think what we're trying to build with AI are subservient intelligences that align with our own needs 1/

Some systems do implement short-timescale retraining, e.g. TikTok's recommender engine. That allows both rapid responses to world events and also opens an attack vector that must be mitigated. Be careful what you wish for! 16/ https://t.co/Kn0dVY4wKY

Already, conventional ML recommender systems retrained daily have been characterized as "the high-interest credit card" of software engineering. Add short training loops to that and you open the door to exploits  that change system behaviour maliciously 15/https://t.co/iDUcppQwpE

Some good ideas for a biological system turn out to be pretty bad ideas when translated to engineering systems. For instance, humans learn at multiple time scales, retraining themselves as new data arrives. From an MLOps perspective, this is a nightmare 14/

This is a great neuro idea that should be applicable to AI. However, giving AI access to a REPL, the internet, actuators, etc. raises real concerns for AI safety. I don't want to get all paperclip-factory doom-and-gloom on you but we should red team before deploying 13/

On another subject: some recent papers take strong stances about AI needing to be embodied, e.g. https://t.co/bZvmBG5h5h, https://t.co/5xo6xsc6GH. People are embodied, and I've argued that embodiment allows the brain to learn good representations 12/ https://t.co/N55gpiUPIV

...even if those actions are in some sense objectively better than the alternative. You want the AI to be human-aligned, even at the cost of efficiency or elegance. I think neuro-inspired-and-aligned vision is particularly promising here 11/

Take (self-)driving for example. The optimal policy for driving is not the same across time and place. If I apply a Los Angeles driver's policy in, say, Montreal, it will not work well. Furthermore, unexpected actions by the AI will scare drivers 10/
I do think there's value in using human data to align existing AI to human expectations and values. Ideally, the AI would form a theory-of-mind of the human 9/ https://t.co/LvU7xZZlEA

I love brains and I think we should study them more through curiosity-based research for their own sake. But to influence ML, I think we should just read old textbooks. The big ideas are probably already out there. 8/ https://t.co/jJ3OggMY9F

Cost per labelled data point is currently not competitive for neuro data vs. other kinds of sensors. That doesn't mean a very smart neuro group will never contribute a new neuro idea to AGI; I'm just saying it's really hard to do so in a directed way. 7/

New-data-dependent findings have a lot of headwind against them, in addition to latency. Moore's law scales chips faster than electrophysiology recordings (though perhaps not optical recordings). We're scaling AI training extremely fast 6/ https://t.co/faOv0a99I7

MLPs, CNNs, RL were built on decades-old neuroscience insights. One potential reason is that doing bio experiments takes a long time. If experiments are anchored on *latest ML fad*, by the time they're done, ML has moved on 5/ https://t.co/fOqIfL9yoh

I find no fault in this as a backward-looking argument: it's happened before, why wouldn't it happen again?). I'm pretty skeptical when a neuroscientist doing new lab work says their results might be relevant to AI. I can't think of an instance where this has happened 4/

A common argument for neuro-inspired AI goes: people (and other mammals, birds and cephalopods) are generally intelligent agents (AGIs). To make machine AGIs, we should study biological AGIs. Historically, neuro has led to MLPs, CNNs, RL https://t.co/JcJ0PZ385G 3/

The highest levels of the dorsal stream integrate visual & vestibular inputs, and motor efference copy. By learning to cross-predict across modalities, the brain could self-organize to learn good representations! You don't need a million supervised labels! 13/

Why am I excited about this paper? It quantitatively explains the responses of single neurons (explains the data), it finds a functional reason for the responses (to enable self-motion estimation), but most importantly, it's biologically plausible! 12/
Together with recent work from @ReubenRideaux and @stereogoggles, we're starting to get a pretty comprehensive account for what the dorsal stream does and how. 11/

That's the qualitative, what about the quantitative? We assembled 5 different single-neuron datasets from 3 different dorsal stream areas, and tested against a dozen models. Our network, dubbed DorsalNet, best fit the data. 10/ https://t.co/k3gxxKXKs3

What's interesting is that if you train a similar deep net on a different task - categorizing movieclips - you get very different RFs, not dorsal-like at all, like this one which seems to like walking and dancing sequences. The task matters! 9/ More here: https://t.co/hGMVh8tprg https://t.co/ADjuxRON1O

Lo and behold, we saw complex motion representations emerge in the trained network. We saw direction selectivity, speed invariance, pattern selectivity and complex motion selectivity appear in an orderly fashion, similar to the dorsal stream 8/ https://t.co/0N3cZyBZio

To test this, we generated short movie sequences simulating self-motion in AirSim, a drone simulation environment. We trained a deep 3d resnet to predict the parameters of self-motion from the sequences 7/ https://t.co/rGMZrizaaX

Even animals with primitive vision stabilize the retinal image during self-motion - the modest nautilus uses it pinhole eyes to orient itself in a rotating drum. Could the visual system self-organize to stabilize images? 6/ https://t.co/wlbebwVYZm

Most of the motion that the visual system sees is due to self-motion. Yes, the world around us moves - cars and baseballs and other people - but by walking around, we're responsible for most motion falling on our retinas 5/ https://t.co/b4tOI8btQp

But wait, isn't this just eyetracking? Is mind control *just* looking at the thing? The decoding is mostly driven by eye position, but attention also modulates the signal. Attention increases the effective contrast of stimuli and spatial resolution 8/n

They use high-frequency patterns made of lines with shadows. They're very visible when seen in the center of the eye, but hard to see from the corner - the white lines blur with the shadows to make a solid gray that blends with the background. You can test this yourself 7/n

Nextmind uses a more clever approach; instead of maximizing the total visual response with big flashing patterns, they maximize the difference between the difference response in the fovea and periphery using a specially chosen pattern. 6/n https://t.co/oOUpAmwJzM

The big problem: flashing lights are super annoying! If you decrease the contrast of the lights, it's less annoying, but it takes more trials for the classifier to detect the pattern. This is the fundamental UX trade-off of using visually evoked potentials for VR mind control 5/n

You can use this principle to create a 2d or VR interface where you select objects by looking at buttons with flashing lights. You train a classifier to tell the difference between looking and not looking at a flashing light. Hence, mind control! 4/n

The high-resolution part of the eye, the fovea, is over-represented in cortex. So when you're staring directly at a flashing light, it creates a larger response over visual cortex than when you're looking at it from the corner of the eye. 3/n https://t.co/8CpEB0tTaT
